answers.author: Martha Perego
answers.text:
ICMA members who are working in local government should refrain from engaging in any activity on behalf of a candidate for elected public office.  That includes offering endorsements.  Because this position is ultimately subject to voter approval, I think the County Executive was correct in declining to provide an endorsement.

author: Michael Williams
text:
I am applying for appointment as a judge to the Superior Court of California in the county where the County Executive Officer works.  I have asked her to recommend me to the Governor, but she is of the opinion that the Code of Ethics which forbids political activity for elected officials bars her from this endorsement.
In California judges are typically appointed, but subsequently every 6 years must run for office.  When there is an open seat, and no judge has been appointed to fill out a term, there can be a contested election.  In my case, this would be an appointment until the retiring judge's term expires, in three years, and thereupon there could be a contested election.  
Does the Code of Ethics forbid an endorsement to the Governor for this appointment?
title: A local county executive officer's recommendation for appointment to the superior court
